awd_titl_txt: Toward a DNA Nanoprocessor: Optimization of Tile-Associated DNA Circuits
awd_abstract_narration:
A nano-scale processor that uses individual molecules as operational units is a promising alternative to the modern computers that use semiconductor microprocessors. A computer built from molecules is potentially smaller and consumes less energy than its electronic counterpart. A long-term goal of this project is to construct a molecular scale processor from biological molecules, called DNA oligonucleotides. An additional advantage of such DNA-based computers is their biocompatibility, which is the ability to interact with biological molecules, cells and even organs in a controlled fashion. This property is crucial in application of molecular devices in living organisms for the control and corrections of metabolic functions, or in clinical tests for diagnosis of human genetic and infectious diseases. 

Recently, connectable logic units made of DNA oligonucleotides have been developed by implementing an original design that supports communication between logic gates made of DNA oligonucleotides. In the prior studies, a set of communicating AND, NOT and OR logic gates was designed and characterized. It was demonstrated that such logic gates have advantages over conventional technologies in the analysis of nucleic acid sequences of pathogenic bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The communicating gates were attached to the DNA tiles to produce simple logic circuits, a counterpart of logic circuit used in modern computers. This project makes next three steps in the development of a DNA nanoprocessor. First, DNA circuits will be powered by chemical reactions to provide energy for continuous operation of the DNA computer. Next step is to achieve re-settable and re-usable mode of operation, such that the DNA computer can be used multiple times for logic operations. This will be achieved by using biocatalysts, such as enzymes and deoxyribozymes which digest DNA inputs, thus resetting the molecular devise in its original state. Third, larger-scale integration of DNA logic units will be achieved. More complex integrated circuits can solve more complex computational tasks. This will be achieved using most recent developments in DNA nanotechnology - controllable self-association of DNA strands in predesigned structures.  To sum up, this project will solve three important problems of molecular computation on the way to the production of a first DNA nanoprocessor. This will lay a foundation for the future DNA nanoprocessors, a key component of smart medical molecular nanodevices of the future. The research will be integrated with education through introducing research topics into undergraduate teaching, research training of students at undergraduate and graduate levels, and the outreach program through partnerships with Central Florida high schools.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Bottom-up organization of molecular circuits is a promising alternative to the conventional fabrication of semiconductor microprocessors by photolithography. This approach can eventually lead to a molecular computer, which is smaller and consumes less energy than its electronic counterpart. Our long-term goal is to construct a molecular scale nanoprocessor based on DNA logic gates. An additional advantage of a DNA-based computer is its biocompatibility, which may enable its application in living organisms and/or for analysis of DNA and RNA in vivo or in vitro. While a number of DNA logic gates and initial DNA circuits were proposed prior to this project a number of technical issued remained to be solved. Here we addressed the following issues in the developing of DNA logic gates: universal connectivity;, precise localization of integrated gates on a two-dimensional platform, powering the DNA circuits by means of chemical reactions, re-setting the processor operations, larger-scale integration of logic gates.

Intellectual merit.  In this project we proposed and experimentally tested several solutions of the major problems on the way to production of a first DNA nano-processor, thus creating a basis for future DNA computer. A novel technological solutions toward development of a smaller and biocompatible counterpart of the modern silicon processors is suggested.

 

Broader impact. Computer technologies: New designs of DNA-based hardware for molecular computation was developed and tested. The hardware has advantages over alternative developments in being easily controllable by attachment to defined position on a DNA nanochip, and in ability to be re-used multiple times.

Nanotechnology: Approaches for attachment of DNA logic gates to precise locations on DNA tiles.

Biological and medical sciences: The information-processing system, developed in this project, operated at room temperature in near physiological buffers and, therefore, are biocompatible. DNA-based logic units were used for detection and genotyping of DNA and RNA analytes, important for the diagnosis of human diseases.

Popularization of Science: The results of the project were published in leading research journals, as well disseminated at national conferences.

Education: The results of this research were integrated undergraduate and graduate courses. Ten undergraduate and 5 graduate students were trained in laboratory techniques and DNA nanotechnology. The outreach activity was conducted through partnerships with Lake Highland Preparatory School situated in Orlando.

Involvement of Minorities: African American and female students were involved in all aspects of the proposed project in its first year.


Last Modified: 09/14/2018
Modified by: Dmitry Kolpashchikov
